text: Words and Pictures, or possibly words versus pictures, with particular reference to science fiction as the subject of our discussion today, with me are Theodore Sturgeon, whose stature as a writer we have noted in the past. His most recent collection of stories is called Visions and Venturers. Lloyd Bigel, a writer currently on the faculty at Eastern Michigan University. His stories have appeared widely in various science fiction magazines, including the new Omni, and he has had some 14 books published. And James R. Odbert, an illustrator, whose work has accompanied stories by Theodore Sturgeon, including the new Visions and Venturers, and any number of other science fiction writers. He hails from Minneapolis, where I understand Gordon Dixon also comes from. Gordon Dixon's new book, Pro, was illustrated by Mr. Odbert. Jim, what, in your view, is the role of the illustrator, particularly in science fiction? Are you a crutch for the author or an equal? Well, not an equal, but I certainly hope not a crutch. I feel the illustrator should embellish the story. He adds to it, gives it more richness and depth with the illustrations, particularly if he can work closely with the author so that he can let you see things that the author did not describe but had in mind when he was doing the story. I've mentioned Gordon Dixon. Was he influential in getting you started, let's say, in illustrating science fiction? Well, he was influential in getting me into the book illustration part of it. I've been doing illustration for quite some time, but when I got into the books, Gordy was very influential in getting me started in book illustration. What other kinds of work have you done? My basis was in industrial design, which actually works nicely into illustration, particularly the hardware and the technical end of it. Do you find it difficult on occasion to do something to accompany a story? Not really. More it's difficult finding the real feel of the story and doing the illustration to fit the feel. The things are not difficult. It's the feeling that's harder to find and to bring across. There have been very few really great illustrators down through the years. In my own experience, I'm reminded of N.C. Wyeth and people like that illustrating Stephenson and other writers, but their names simply don't stand out, and I guess one reason is that not too many of the older books actually contained illustrations, or very few illustrations. So often today one gets the impression that the illustration is an aide to the child or perhaps the semi-literate adult in getting him over the problem of reading. How do you feel about that, Mr. Sturgeon? In an interesting time, we have had a long time now we haven't had any illustrations at all. Earlier, however, they did. I can remember turn-of-the-century books that always had a Francis piece, and often then these very careful steel engravings and woodcuts and things like that all the way through. We got away from that. We're getting back to it again. And more and more you'll find interior illustrations in books. And some publishers and editors, like Byron Price in New York, are doing a whole series of novels which are almost half and half illustration and copy, which is very interesting. I want to hand a palm to Mr. Oddbert here. He's Jim Oddbert. He really and truly reads what he illustrates. it happens that this copy of Visions and Ventures fell into my hands last night for the very first time the local B. Dalton bookstore made a special effort and got them out pre-publication it'll probably be out generally next week but they got into stock how I don't know I've tried to do this myself and failed and the manager down there is really on top of it so I had my first look at it and at Jim's drawings last night I was very, very pleased He clearly has carefully read each story And as he said, the feel of it He's gotten that over very well indeed Where I write horror, he's got a horror drawing Where it tends to be more mechanistic In a computer story, for example It's neat and it's laid out And you immediately get the feel of the story You did not work with him No In the preparation of the art No, in this case, no I haven't I've been all across the spectrum with artists working Sometimes not knowing who they are Some of them I never did find out who they were. And in other cases, I've written stories from a painting, an editor will buy a painting he likes, and say, hey, I've got no story to go with this. I want to get into that subject in just a moment. But let me ask you, first of all, Lloyd Beagle, do you have a feeling sometimes that illustrations have a tendency to drive out good writing, perhaps? I had an interesting experience with a novel of mine called The Light That Never Was, which coincidentally is a novel about art, and the cover painting for the paperback book was done by Kelly Freese, who was excellent. And the scene that he drew for the cover painting does not occur in the book anywhere. But in that scene, he delineates one of the major themes of the novel beautifully. The cover could stand entirely by itself. It tells its own story, which is entirely different from the story of my novel, but it delineates the theme of the novel. And with the novel, of course, in conjunction, then it means something additional. Now, if he had done a series of interior drawings on that nature, the reader would have been horribly confused because, again, they would have nothing to do with the story, even if he caught the theme in some way of what the story was about. So in your view, it did add? It did add under those circumstances. as the cover, yes. You know, there's an interesting parallel. We in radio all these years have been convinced that it's an ideal medium for the imaginative as opposed to, let's say, a film or television. In other words, you leave so much up to the imagination of the listener and you don't spell it out for him. And translating some stories into either medium and they can be done very well in radio, but they're ruined the minute you see it. Now, isn't this true to some degree of a science fiction story, that the minute you illustrate it, you take away from the reader the opportunity to make a concept of his own? Well, this is true. Let's say a picture is worth a thousand words, but sometimes the reader's imagination is worth 10,000 words. So it happens that way. Also, it works both ways as far as art and illustration. if you can make a differentiation between the two, I have a French edition of my novel More than Human illustrated by a French artist, the name is Girard. The guy is an extraordinary artist, and the illustrations, the pictures in the book are good art, but poor illustration. I mean, they don't have that, as you said, quality of feel, or the feel they have is not the same as the feel of the story. Once again, when you're illustrating a story, it's sometimes very important not to add too much to the story, or to give away the story, particularly in short stories. You have to be very careful not to give away the punch line, or the end of the story in advance. There's one in Visions and Ventures that after I read the story the immediate illustration that sprung into my mind looked very nice and everything, and I realized I couldn't do it because it would tell the punchline at the end of the story before it would just be anticlimactic when they read the story. Do you differentiate in your own mind between, as Mr. Sturgeon has said, a work of art and an illustration? No. No. I don't. An illustration can be a work of art. Let me put it. An illustration should be a work of art. Not can be, but it really should be. Not all works of arts are illustration. but a good illustration should be a work of art I absolutely agree with you with that the differentiation I made particularly is one in that French book struck me particularly because nobody could fault the man as an artist his black and whites are simply extraordinary he used a combination of I think fine pen and airbrush in black and white and simply amazing work that he did but they were not good illustrations as far as the story was concerned. No, I have of course, well the ones that you mention Wyeth, for example, I remember he did a... do you remember Howard Pyle's book of pirates? Uh-huh, yes. Didn't Fayet do those illustrations? I think so. They were gorgeous illustrations and real art, there are no question about it. Way back when novels were first coming out and illustration was part of it, Gustav Do Titus Yeah. Oh, my word. And he's still referred to as an illustrator, but these are works of art, and too many people... I don't think you can differentiate between artist and illustrator. Not really. A good illustrator is an artist. Not all artists are good illustrators. Again, it's a subclass. So you can have marvelous art that is not illustrated. That was just my point. In this case of fine art, it was not a good illustrator. There are many times certain illustrations by a particular illustrator become very much identified with the story and with the character. I mean, Dickens or Alice in Wonderland, other illustrators have tried to illustrate them. Oh no, Alice without any illustrations. But the original will probably always simply accompany that story. I really feel that a lot of that is that it's a great story, which inspires the first artist to get their hands on it. And the definition, the identification is with the first man that does it. And if he does it properly nobody else can do it. Deserved to be repeated. No. Lloyd, Mr. Sturgeon a moment ago mentioned this business of commissioning a story to go along with an already prepared illustration. And you've written about this in one of the introductions to your stories. What's your feeling about this? You think this is degrading the writer? I thought it was a challenge to try it. I've just done it once. I don't think I would like to write very much. I'd rather make my own pictures. Well, you come over to the other side of the field for a while. This is what we do all the time. I've always found the same thing as a challenge. I've done it a number of times. As a matter of fact, one of the stories in Visions and Venturers, One Foot in the Grave, Weird Tales bought a cover, a very strange painting by, I think, Joe Pugnani. and nobody could make any sense of it, the editor had bought it because he liked it. And I had the job of writing a story into it and it wasn't easy, but I got it all in. In this new book of yours, Visions and Venturers, is the cover illustration done by you? No. It's done by a different person. And I noticed that in the Gordon Dixon Pro, which I have in front of me, there again, the cover illustration is by someone else. does that create problems? Yes it does. Part of the reason that I do not do a lot of color work, I'm partially color blind. No kidding. No, true. Isn't that something? And the balance of black and white is what I feel I do best and what I enjoy doing most. You certainly do it well, there's no question about. But the person that did the cover on Pro had never seen my black and white interiors when he did the cover, and as a result it's particularly noticeable on the hero who's in the front and on the aliens in the background because Gordy and I worked very long and hard on trying to figure out just what the aliens looked like. And the cover alien is something entirely different. I noticed the uniform on the man in there is different from the uniform that you have him wearing. So the cover, I suppose, is there to get you inside the story and then once you're inside the illustrator is going to have to be much closer to the story. You know, the thing is that the cover should be able to draw you in and truly reflect the story. Too often the cover has nothing to do with the story. mm-hmm it's a grabber yeah that that's that's essentially all it's they're attempting to do is to put something there that looks science fictiony that will grab your eye and make you pick it up and read it and i i really don't have any objections with them wanting you wanting to grab you and make you pick it up and read it but i think they should be able to do it and truly reflect what's inside the book I think that too many people sometimes get this really bad feeling because the cover and the book do not reflect one another Gordon Dixon isn't here to defend himself but I'd like to just use this as a kickoff for a discussion of this business of working the author, working together with the illustrator In his book Pro, well, right here on page two, for instance, he says, in her white slacks and shirt with only the med service badge for color on the pocket, she was a vibrant sight, her hair was as black as obsidian, etc. And I look across the page at your illustration and denote that the med service badge is on her sleeve rather than her pocket. But then I went on to read and everywhere else through the book, Gordon Dixon refers to the patch as being on the sleeve. And this raises an interesting question. Is this our forgetful authors? No, no, it's just that the lady had two shirts. Two shirts. And that has happened, you know? It's perfectly understandable, but I was just struck by that right at the beginning. I'll tell the funnier one than that on myself. I did a novel called The Still Small Voice of Trumpets, in which i very carefully designed uh an alien trumpet and i insisted when they were going to put the trumpeter on the jacket of the hardcover edition that i approve the drawing first so the we had these one arm trumpet players and the he drew one of those for the jacket so i very carefully went over the trumpet and made certain and exchanged letters with the artist and got that trumpet exactly the way that I wanted it and we were all pleased and several years later someone came to me and said why is a trumpeter holding his trumpet in the wrong hand and I had completely overlooked the fact that all these trumpeters were missing the left arm and the artist drew a trumpeter holding the trumpet in his left arm we've had other experiences like that have you not I think all authors have had this kind of experience probably a second immediate subject But you have to, I think, quickly mention your career as a cellist. It's a funny story. Do you mind? Yes. Well, I've been a clarinetist since I was nine years old, and I got an advanced copy of the Dust Jacket on a new novel which had a little biography on it. And this means that Doubleday already had printed up enough for the first edition of the book, and they sent me a few. And the biography said, although he now is a full time writer, he formerly was a musician and he still enjoys playing the cello and chamber music in his native state of Michigan. So I got a hold of my editor at Doubleday and I said, I've been a clarinetist since I was nine years old. Where did you get the idea that I played the cello? And she said, well, it's a beautiful instrument. And if you start lessons right now, perhaps by the time the book is published, we'll be telling the truth. So I finally got things stopped so they would stop calling me a cellist, including catching the same error a couple of years later before it got into print and then I got the British edition of this same book and the British publisher based the copy on the American edition and now I am an internationally famous cellist. Well we'll invite you to perform. That's got to come along. Back on the other subject, there was, if I might put in one thing that helps, really, is that when I went through and read another book I was illustrating, the author had two completely different descriptions in size of an alien in the front and the back, and I caught it where the editors hadn't caught it or anything. because I was reading for illustrating. The editors were simply reading to correct. And in that particular case, I was able to catch it pointed out, and they changed one so that the two of them matched. This kind of thing is awfully easy to do in a 300-page book. It is indeed, or for that matter in a television show. I had that experience in television too where one of my lines was knocked out of a... it was a Star Trek as a matter of fact because they brought in another actor and they used a few more frames and they had to cut somewhere. So they cut that. They had their noses so close to the production that they overlooked the fact that that particular line is the one that brought the entire plot into it. The only thing it made the entire plot mean anything so that without it the whole show would have been absolutely nothing. And I happened to be on the set at the time and able to correct it. But you're not always that lucky. No, it's very strange when you're reading a novel. I sit down with a pad and I will go through the manuscript and underscore descriptions of persons and write down. And I haven't run across it yet, but I'm sure that someday I'll find that he has black hair in the beginning and by the end of the book he's a blonde. And it's very easy to lose sight of the broad range when you're right down close to it. That's right. You'd think that when these errors are made, it's more often the fault of the author than the illustrator. No, quite often the illustrator doesn't even have a manuscript. He's got some art director that's told him the type of picture he wants, and he draws. There was another very interesting one. This was for one of Gordy's books. I was sitting talking to him, and he was very unhappy with the cover that they had done for it. Very, very unhappy. And I'd read the story, so I had a pad in front, and I made a very quick sketch of maybe two or three minutes and said, I'd always thought this would be kind of a nice cover, just a black-and-white sketch. And he said, I love it. Can I have a copy of it? So I said, here, sure, take the original. So he turned around, without my knowledge, sent it off to the people that were putting the book, and they liked it and wrote me back and asked if they could use it as the basis for a drawing. And I said, sure, no problem. So they did. Well, it's about a sword. And this sword plays a prominent part in the cover sketch, which actually has two prongs coming out of a piece that covers the hand completely. They help it. It covers the hand. And I had simply made two quick lines. When it came out on the cover, the illustrator had made it a saber that is wide as the two lines of the prongs of the sword. Filled in between them and made it work. Because he had obviously not read the story, but here I had just two lines very quickly made, and he closed them up. These gross errors are very disconcerting. Oh, they are, yeah. But so many of them, as you pointed out, are large errors that you have your nose too close to it to be able to see. I've had a left-handed villain where the whole plot turned on his left-handedness, John wielding a knife with his right hand, and six-fingered people described throughout a novel are drawn with five fingers Things like such Well, again I think this is because I think that the illustrators really don't see the manuscripts They aren't even allowed to see them The art director comes in and describes what he wants and that's what he gets Yeah, I think I wish it could be virtually a rigorous law or convention that the artists read. Also, the people who write book jackets, again, that strays a little bit from the immediate subject, but my God, it ought to be in writers' contracts that the people who write blurbs on book jackets will have read the copy of the book. Yes. Well, good. We can't blame either the illustrators or the authors, but the absent editors will have to take the blame right here. You know, you do have a point there. It really should be up to an editor to go over the whole thing, complete the illustrations and the book, in one final check to see that everything conforms. That really would solve the problem. You put your finger on it. I don't want to resolve myself or I've pulled baubles like that and I have, changing the color of the hair or something or the stature. But it's up to an editor to jump on those things and they don't, always. So occasionally a very good copy editor will catch such mistakes. And you receive a query when you get the copy-edited manuscript back saying his hair is brown on page 14. Right, that is. Funk and Wagnell's company was always meticulous about that. Maybe because they were involved in Uncle Chris with dictionaries and so on. They were staffed by a bunch of lexicographers. Was that you that had, Lloyd, that had, were a copy-editor caught an error in grammar in an alien language. Oh, me. I think that was Stanley Smith. Yes, that's right. We were talking to Stanley yesterday, and he had made up an alien language. And the copy editor caught an error in grammar, which they had deduced from reading the story. The copy editor was really on top of it. It seems like it's a very short step from illustrating science fiction writing to stage design, costume design for films and television shows. Have you gone that step, Jim? No, I haven't gone into that at all. I would like to get into it eventually, but as a full-time illustrator, I am fairly new to the field. I've only been full-time illustrating one year. Is that right? I've been an artist for approximately 25 years professionally but full-time illustrator only for the past year. And so I haven't gotten into that yet. I'm looking forward to it. The fans, however, if you go to a science fiction convention and see their costume ball, some of the costumes are absolutely beautiful and taken from illustrations in science fiction magazines as well of course as television and the movies but some of them are absolutely breathtaking and very meticulously done from the stories and from the illustrations in magazines well it's the fans that always pull us up short when we make mistakes it really is they read much closer than I write. Gentlemen, it's been delightful talking with you. I want to thank you all very much for discussing this very important subject of art illustration and science fiction writing. Theodore Sturgeon and Lloyd Bigel are present authors and illustrator James R. Otbert. Thank you for joining me today. Thank you, Ray. Thank you very much. Thank you.

segments.text: Words and Pictures, or possibly words versus pictures, with particular reference to science
fiction as the subject of our discussion today, with me are Theodore Sturgeon, whose
stature as a writer we have noted in the past. His most recent collection of stories is called
Visions and Venturers. Lloyd Bigel, a writer currently on the faculty at Eastern Michigan
University. His stories have appeared widely in various science fiction magazines, including the
new Omni, and he has had some 14 books published. And James R. Odbert, an illustrator, whose work
has accompanied stories by Theodore Sturgeon, including the new Visions and Venturers, and
any number of other science fiction writers. He hails from Minneapolis, where I understand
Gordon Dixon also comes from. Gordon Dixon's new book, Pro, was illustrated by Mr. Odbert.
Jim, what, in your view, is the role of the illustrator, particularly in science fiction?
Are you a crutch for the author or an equal?
Well, not an equal, but I certainly hope not a crutch.
I feel the illustrator should embellish the story.
He adds to it, gives it more richness and depth with the illustrations,
particularly if he can work closely with the author
so that he can let you see things that the author did not describe
but had in mind when he was doing the story.
I've mentioned Gordon Dixon.
Was he influential in getting you started, let's say,
in illustrating science fiction?
Well, he was influential in getting me
into the book illustration part of it.
I've been doing illustration for quite some time,
but when I got into the books,
Gordy was very influential
in getting me started in book illustration.
What other kinds of work have you done?
My basis was in industrial design, which
actually works nicely into illustration, particularly the hardware and the technical
end of it.
Do you find it difficult on occasion to do something to accompany a story?
Not really.
More it's difficult finding the real feel of the story
and doing the illustration to fit the feel.
The things are not difficult.
It's the feeling that's harder to find and to bring across.
There have been very few really great illustrators down through the years.
In my own experience, I'm reminded of N.C. Wyeth
and people like that illustrating Stephenson and other writers,
but their names simply don't stand out,
and I guess one reason is that not too many of the older books
actually contained illustrations, or very few illustrations.
So often today one gets the impression that the illustration
is an aide to the child
or perhaps the semi-literate adult
in getting him over the problem of reading.
How do you feel about that, Mr. Sturgeon?
In an interesting time,
we have had a long time now
we haven't had any illustrations at all.
Earlier, however, they did.
I can remember turn-of-the-century books
that always had a Francis piece,
and often then these very careful
steel engravings and woodcuts
and things like that all the way through.
We got away from that.
We're getting back to it again.
And more and more you'll find interior illustrations in books.
And some publishers and editors, like Byron Price in New York,
are doing a whole series of novels which are almost half and half illustration and copy,
which is very interesting.
I want to hand a palm to Mr. Oddbert here.
He's Jim Oddbert.
He really and truly reads what he illustrates.
it happens that this copy of Visions
and Ventures fell into my hands last night
for the very first time
the local B. Dalton bookstore made a special effort
and got them out pre-publication
it'll probably be out generally next week
but they got into stock
how I don't know
I've tried to do this myself and failed
and the manager down there is really on top of it
so I had my first look at it
and at Jim's drawings last night
I was very, very pleased
He clearly has carefully read each story
And as he said, the feel of it
He's gotten that over very well indeed
Where I write horror, he's got a horror drawing
Where it tends to be more mechanistic
In a computer story, for example
It's neat and it's laid out
And you immediately get the feel of the story
You did not work with him
No
In the preparation of the art
No, in this case, no I haven't
I've been all across the spectrum with artists working
Sometimes not knowing who they are
Some of them I never did find out who they were.
And in other cases, I've written stories from a painting,
an editor will buy a painting he likes,
and say, hey, I've got no story to go with this.
I want to get into that subject in just a moment.
But let me ask you, first of all, Lloyd Beagle,
do you have a feeling sometimes that illustrations have a tendency
to drive out good writing, perhaps?
I had an interesting experience with a novel of mine
called The Light That Never Was,
which coincidentally is a novel about art,
and the cover painting for the paperback book
was done by Kelly Freese, who was excellent.
And the scene that he drew for the cover painting
does not occur in the book anywhere.
But in that scene, he delineates
one of the major themes of the novel beautifully.
The cover could stand entirely by itself.
It tells its own story, which is entirely different
from the story of my novel, but it delineates the theme of the novel.
And with the novel, of course, in conjunction,
then it means something additional.
Now, if he had done a series of interior drawings on that nature,
the reader would have been horribly confused
because, again, they would have nothing to do with the story,
even if he caught the theme in some way of what the story was about.
So in your view, it did add?
It did add under those circumstances.
as the cover, yes.
You know, there's an interesting parallel.
We in radio all these years have been convinced
that it's an ideal medium for the imaginative
as opposed to, let's say, a film or television.
In other words, you leave so much up to the imagination of the listener
and you don't spell it out for him.
And translating some stories into either medium
and they can be done very well in radio, but they're ruined the minute you see it.
Now, isn't this true to some degree of a science fiction story,
that the minute you illustrate it, you take away from the reader
the opportunity to make a concept of his own?
Well, this is true.
Let's say a picture is worth a thousand words,
but sometimes the reader's imagination is worth 10,000 words.
So it happens that way.
Also, it works both ways as far as art and illustration.
if you can make a differentiation between the two,
I have a French edition of my novel More than Human
illustrated by a French artist,
the name is Girard.
The guy is an extraordinary artist,
and the illustrations,
the pictures in the book are good art,
but poor illustration.
I mean, they don't have that,
as you said, quality of feel,
or the feel they have is not the same
as the feel of the story.
Once again, when you're illustrating a story, it's sometimes very important not to
add too much to the story, or to give away the story, particularly in short stories.
You have to be very careful not to give away the punch line, or the end of the story in advance.
There's one in Visions and Ventures that after I read the story the immediate illustration
that sprung into my mind looked very nice and everything, and I realized I couldn't
do it because it would tell the punchline at the end of the story before it would just
be anticlimactic when they read the story.
Do you differentiate in your own mind between, as Mr. Sturgeon has said, a work of art and an illustration?
No. No. I don't.
An illustration can be a work of art.
Let me put it. An illustration should be a work of art.
Not can be, but it really should be.
Not all works of arts are illustration.
but a good illustration
should be a work of art
I absolutely agree with you with that
the differentiation I made particularly
is one in that French book
struck me particularly
because nobody could fault the man
as an artist
his black and whites
are simply extraordinary
he used a combination of I think fine pen
and airbrush in black and white
and simply amazing work
that he did but they were not good
illustrations as far as the story was concerned.
No, I have of course, well the ones that you mention Wyeth, for example, I remember he
did a... do you remember Howard Pyle's book of pirates?
Uh-huh, yes.
Didn't Fayet do those illustrations?
I think so.
They were gorgeous illustrations and real art, there are no question about it.
Way back when novels were first coming out and illustration was part of it, Gustav Do Titus
Yeah.
Oh, my word.
And he's still referred to as an illustrator,
but these are works of art,
and too many people...
I don't think you can differentiate
between artist and illustrator.
Not really.
A good illustrator is an artist.
Not all artists are good illustrators.
Again, it's a subclass.
So you can have marvelous art that is not illustrated.
That was just my point.
In this case of fine art, it was not a good illustrator.
There are many times certain illustrations by a particular illustrator become very much
identified with the story and with the character.
I mean, Dickens or Alice in Wonderland, other illustrators have tried to illustrate them.
Oh no, Alice without any illustrations.
But the original will probably always simply accompany that story.
I really feel that a lot of that is that it's a great story,
which inspires the first artist to get their hands on it.
And the definition, the identification is with the first man that does it.
And if he does it properly nobody else can do it.
Deserved to be repeated.
No.
Lloyd, Mr. Sturgeon a moment ago mentioned this business of commissioning a story
to go along with an already prepared illustration.
And you've written about this in one of the introductions to your stories.
What's your feeling about this?
You think this is degrading the writer?
I thought it was a challenge to try it.
I've just done it once.
I don't think I would like to write very much.
I'd rather make my own pictures.
Well, you come over to the other side of the field for a while.
This is what we do all the time.
I've always found the same thing as a challenge.
I've done it a number of times.
As a matter of fact, one of the stories in Visions and Venturers,
One Foot in the Grave, Weird Tales bought a cover,
a very strange painting by, I think, Joe Pugnani.
and nobody could make any sense of it,
the editor had bought it because he liked it.
And I had the job of writing a story into it
and it wasn't easy, but I got it all in.
In this new book of yours, Visions and Venturers,
is the cover illustration done by you?
No.
It's done by a different person.
And I noticed that in the Gordon Dixon Pro,
which I have in front of me,
there again, the cover illustration is by someone else.
does that create problems? Yes it does. Part of the reason that I do not do a lot of color
work, I'm partially color blind. No kidding. No, true. Isn't that something? And the balance
of black and white is what I feel I do best and what I enjoy doing most. You certainly
do it well, there's no question about. But the person that did the cover on Pro had never
seen my
